awd_titl_txt: Workshop for Industry-Academia Collaboration in Advanced Manufacturing; 2020 ASME International MSEC and 48th NAMRC; Cincinnati, Ohio; 22-23 June 2020
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides a forum to facilitate collaboration between industry and academia in advanced-manufacturing research, education, and workforce development. The workshop will be held in conjunction with the North American Manufacturing Research Conference (NAMRC) and the Manufacturing Science and Engineering Conference (MSEC) held 22-23 June 2020, in Cincinnati, Ohio. Attendees from industry, academia and government will come together to identify research needs to advance U.S. manufacturing, discuss challenges, and identify the resources required to foster and build strong collaborations. Representatives from select USA Manufacturing Institutes will share their research roadmaps as an aid to identify fundamental research projects to resolve real-world industry manufacturing problems. Presentations and a summary of the discussions will be made publicly available on the workshop website and a follow-up virtual meeting will be scheduled within six months of the workshop, followed by a full report.

The overall objectives of the workshop are to (1) identify the future research needs for promoting the technical innovation ecosystem and the base capabilities and capacity of U.S. manufacturing, (2) identify challenges and benefits of Industry-Academia collaboration, (3) present research roadmaps for selected Manufacturing USA Institutes, (4) formulate fundamental research projects involving real-world problems in industry, and (5) identify resources necessary to conduct the highlighted research projects. This workshop will help not only fill a significant void in the formulation of Industry-Academia partnerships but also encourage partnerships between industry, academia, and governmental agencies. This will help maximize the impact of the governmental support on promoting the base capabilities and capacity of U.S. manufacturing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this project was to provide a forum to facilitate collaboration between academia and industry in advanced-manufacturing research, education, and workforce development by achieving the following goals:

(1)    Highlight the challenges and benefits of Industry-Academia collaboration to foster US advanced manufacturing;

(2)    Identify research needs of US advanced manufacturing with an emphasis on the support of the research underway at selected Manufacturing USA institutes;

(3)    Explore funding programs and mechanisms in NSF to support Industry-Academia collaboration;

(4)    Formulate fundamental research topics to resolve the real-world industrial problems;

(5)    Identify resources (knowledge, skills, infrastructures, experience, and industry support) needed to conduct the research; and

(6)    Foster future collaboration between participants.

 

The workshop was held to fully achieve the stated goals and maximize the impact of the workshop:

Part 1: May 19-21, 2021—Online Workshop

Part 2: September 24, 2021—Follow-up Meeting 1 (Online)

Part 3: June 26, 2022—Follow-up Meeting 2 (Face-to-face)

In Workshop Part 1, there were about 200 participants from academia, industry, and federal agencies. We invited 31 speakers from Manufacturing USA institutes, federal agencies, industry, academia, and NSF to discuss their programs promoting Industry-Academia collaborations and to share their experiences working with partners from Industry and Academia. The panelists’ speeches and the subsequent discussion promoted awareness of not only various funding programs and mechanisms but also the importance of collaboration with multidisciplinary parties to create successful and transformative research projects. This workshop included breakout sessions to discuss (1) top challenges to establishing successful collaborations and mechanisms to assist in collaborations and (2) collaboration focusing on future manufacturing. These sessions exposed the essential problems that hinder the growth of Industry-Academia collaboration. In addition, prospective research topics that are needed for future US manufacturing were discussed.

In Workshop Part 2, there were about 80 participants from academia, industry, and federal agencies. We invited 10 speakers including NSF program directors and representatives from Manufacturing USA institutes, federal agencies, industry, and professional societies. In contrast to Workshop 1, Workshop 2 had fewer speakers, and a longer time was allotted for Q&A. Speakers and participants discussed how to further promote Industry-Academia collaboration and what we should do to improve the future of manufacturing. In both Part 1 and Part 2, we created networking sessions in which several NSF program directors were able to spend time with Workshop participants. These networking sessions provided opportunities for Workshop participants to frankly ask NSF program directors questions related to their research topics and funding.

We also created two methods to promote the Workshop mission beyond the events in May and September 2021. One method included posting 209 attendees’ profiles and 110 research portfolios on the workshop website. The information is public and enables participants to review other participants’ profiles and research portfolios and to identify potential collaborators. The other method was the Industry-Academia Collaboration Initiation Grant; 17 awardees were identified from 20 applications. This grant program helped participants to visit potential collaborators and discuss research projects. As a result, 8 proposals were submitted, 7 proposals were being prepared for submission, and 1 proposal was selected for award.

Workshop Part 3 was held as a part of the 2022 International Manufacturing Science and Engineering Conference (MSEC 2022) sponsored by the American Society of Manufacturing Engineers and the North American Manufacturing Research Conference (NAMRC 50) sponsored by North American Manufacturing Research Institution of the Society of Manufacturing Engineers (NAMEI/SME). In Workshop Part 3, there were about 70 participants from academia, industry, and federal agencies. We invited 3 speakers from the Industry-Academia Collaboration Initiation Grant recipients and 3 junior professors from minority-serving institutions and 1 junior professor from R2 Doctoral University. Similar to Workshop 2, Workshop 3 had fewer speakers, and a longer time was allotted for Q&A. The panelists shared their successes and failures related to industry-academia collaboration and shared hints and made recommendations about initiating industry-academia collaboration. That was helpful for participants, especially for junior faculty and representatives of small-and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The issues discussed in the workshop ran from the institution level to the societal level, we could not immediately identify solutions to the specific problems above. However, exposing various issues encountered by both industry and academia is significant and the first step in improving the current situation and promoting industry-academia collaboration in advanced manufacturing.

Overall, this workshop showed the benefits of Industry-Academia collaboration in advanced-manufacturing research, education, and workforce development; and the transformative impacts will strengthen the US global leadership in advanced manufacturing.

 


Last Modified: 01/21/2023
Modified by: Hitomi Yamaguchi Greenslet
